questions.text: The following documents are exceptions to oral evidence in court except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Postmortem reports

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Postmortem reports typically require oral testimony to explain the findings, whereas other documents like dying declarations, fingerprint reports, and chemical examiner’s reports are exceptions to the need for oral evidence in court.

questions.text: Leading questions are permitted only in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cross Examination

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand that leading questions are allowed only during cross-examination, as they serve to challenge or clarify a witness's testimony, but they are not permitted during other phases of witness examination or in the recording of dying declarations.

questions.text: An accused died in lock up during the police interrogation. Enquiry in this case will be done by?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Judicial magistrate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand that inquiries into custodial deaths are conducted by Judicial Magistrates to ensure impartiality and prevent conflicts of interest. This is a key part of the legal safeguards in cases of potential abuse of police authority.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy attends the surgery without an adult accompanying him. He has a sore throat. Legally, a general practitioner must:

options.label: B
options.text: Refuse to see him unless a responsible adult is present

options.label: C
options.text: Write to the parent asking them to come to the surgery

questions.correct_answer: A. Examine and prescribe as appropriate
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Examine and prescribe as appropriate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand that minors, under certain conditions, can consent to medical treatment if they are deemed competent to understand the nature and consequences of the treatment. This is based on the concept of Gillick competence .
  • ➤ .

questions.text: A surgeon returns home from a party after many pegs of alcohol and was called to perform an emergency operation. During the operation, the assisting staff noticed the surgeon’s hand shaking and instruments falling. He eventually nicks an artery and the patient collapses. Under which of the following terms will this incident be tried?

options.label: B
options.text: Civil negligence not amounting to criminal negligence

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Criminal negligence

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand that performing a medical procedure while under the influence of alcohol or other impairing substances is a severe breach of professional duty and constitutes criminal negligence, especially when it results in harm to the patient.

questions.text: In the realm of medical practice, the principle of vicarious liability plays a crucial role in determining legal responsibility. Which of the following statements best exemplifies the concept of vicarious liability in cases of medical negligence?

options.label: A
options.text: Medical institutions can only be held responsible for the actions of their employed medical professionals if institution had direct knowledge of the negligence.

options.label: B
options.text: Vicarious liability does not apply when medical professionals commit gross negligence, as such actions are considered beyond the scope of their employment.

options.label: C
options.text: Vicarious liability extends to situations where medical professionals are acting as independent contractors within a medical institution.

options.label: D
options.text: Vicarious liability mandates that medical institutions are immune to legal action if the medical professional involved had a valid license to practice.

questions.correct_answer: C. Vicarious liability extends to situations where medical professionals are acting as independent contractors within a medical institution.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Vicarious liability extends to situations where medical professionals, acting as independent contractors within a medical institution

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand that vicarious liability in medical practice extends to situations where medical professionals, whether full-time employees or independent contractors, act negligently while providing services within a medical institution. The institution can be held liable for these actions, regardless of whether the professional is salaried or working as a consultant.

questions.text: The drumstick shape in the image shown below helps to determine:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Sex

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand that the presence of a Barr body (or Davidson body) in a neutrophil is indicative of a female's sex and is not related to age, race, or stature.

questions.text: Majority of fingerprints in Indians is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Loops

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Loops are the most common fingerprint pattern, both in India and globally.

questions.text: A 25-year-old young male who was a tattoo artist was brought dead to the casualty under mysterious circumstances. His girlfriend reported he had a large tattoo on his right hand, but this was not found on examination. Which structure should be examined to get more idea of the same?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Lymph nodes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tattoo ink can migrate to and accumulate in lymph nodes, making them a crucial structure to examine in cases where tattoos are not visible on the skin.

questions.text: A child who is a victim under POCSO act is brought to the department of forensic medicine for age estimation. The X-ray image of the hand is shown below. What is the likely age of the child?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 13 years

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The pisiform bone appears around the age of 10 to 12 years, and its presence on an X-ray can help in estimating a child's skeletal age.

questions.text: The method of autopsy carried out en masse to remove from tongue to prostate is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Letulle technique

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should memorize that the Letulle technique is an autopsy method where the organs are removed en masse, from the tongue to the prostate, for examination.

questions.text: Identify the image shown below and what does it indicate?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Death

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Retinal Hemorrhages or Tache Noire de la Sclera can be an indicator of death, and the presence of this finding in an eye examination can help confirm postmortem changes.
  • ➤ Retinal Hemorrhages
  • ➤ Tache Noire de la Sclera

questions.text: The image below of liver is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Putrefaction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Foamy or Honeycomb Liver is a characteristic feature of putrefaction , a stage in the decomposition process after death.
  • ➤ Foamy or Honeycomb Liver
  • ➤ putrefaction

questions.text: Correct order of putrefaction?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Brain, Heart, Uterus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should memorize the correct order of putrefaction: brain decays first , followed by heart , and the uterus decays last .
  • ➤ brain decays first
  • ➤ heart
  • ➤ uterus decays last

questions.text: A death certificate is given below. What is the underlying cause of death in this case?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Carcinoma Breast

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The underlying cause of death refers to the condition that initiated the chain of events leading to death. In this case, carcinoma of the breast is the underlying cause, as it led to metastasis, which eventually caused the fatal myocardial infarction.
  • ➤ underlying cause of death
  • ➤ carcinoma of the breast

questions.text: Identify the true statement about the image given below?

options.label: B
options.text: Due to sulphemoglobin accumulation and formation

options.label: D
options.text: It is associated with a case of electrical burns

questions.correct_answer: B. Due to sulphemoglobin accumulation and formation
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Due to sulphemoglobin accumulation and formation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Marbling is a postmortem change that occurs due to the accumulation of sulphemoglobin, typically beginning around 36 to 48 hours after death . It is an important forensic finding during decomposition.
  • ➤ Marbling
  • ➤ 36 to 48 hours after death

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about postmortem changes?

options.label: A
options.text: Greenish discoloration in right iliac fossa is the earliest sign of decomposition.

options.label: B
options.text: In cases of drowning, postmortem hypostasis is seen only in lower limbs.

options.label: C
options.text: Adipocere is seen in bodies recovered from water source

options.label: D
options.text: Cadaveric spasm is seen only in specific group of muscles.

questions.correct_answer: B. In cases of drowning, postmortem hypostasis is seen only in lower limbs.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) In cases of drowning, postmortem hypostasis is seen only in lower limbs.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Postmortem hypostasis is not confined to the lower limbs in drowning cases and can affect any part of the body that is in a dependent position after death.

questions.text: Identify the type of injury from the picture given below:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Incised looking laceration

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Laceration can sometimes resemble an incised wound , especially when blunt force causes a split laceration with abraded or contused margins, despite the clean appearance.
  • ➤ Laceration
  • ➤ incised wound
  • ➤ split laceration

questions.text: A person is found dead in his home. He was living alone. Neighbours called the police when they experienced a foul smell from home. As told by neighbours, the deceased person didn’t interact much with others and was a very quiet person. Dead body was brought for postmortem examination, and following injuries were seen as shown below. Based on above context which statement is true?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) A case of murder

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Defense wounds, typically on the hands and forearms, are indicative of a struggle and are strong evidence of homicide. Hesitation marks are often seen in suicide, but their absence alongside defensive wounds suggests a violent death caused by another individual.

questions.text: A forensic investigator is examining a series of bruises on a victim's body. To determine whether these bruises are artificial or true bruises, which of the following characteristics would be most useful to assess?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Color changes over time

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Color changes over time are an important diagnostic feature of a true bruise, helping forensic investigators determine the nature and age of the injury.
  • ➤ Color changes over time

questions.text: Which of these is not a grievous hurt?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Bruise Over Cheek

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A bruise over the cheek is not classified as grievous hurt because it heals without long-term damage, while grievous hurt refers to more severe and permanent injury
  • ➤ bruise over the cheek

questions.text: In a case of fatality resulting from firearm injuries, the entrance wound displays solely an abrasion collar. The firearm's firing distance probably is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Distant range

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In firearm injuries, the presence of only an abrasion collar at the entrance wound suggests a distant-range shot, where features such as blackening, singeing, and tattooing are absent.
  • ➤ only an abrasion collar
  • ➤ distant-range

questions.text: A dead body is brought for autopsy. On examination of neck, a ligature that was present obliquely, and above the level of the thyroid was seen. The subcutaneous tissue under the mark was white and glistening. What is the cause of death?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hanging

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of hanging , the ligature mark is oblique and above the thyroid , with the subcutaneous tissue under the ligature appearing white and glistening due to compression, distinguishing it from other forms of neck compression or strangulation.
  • ➤ hanging
  • ➤ oblique and above the thyroid

questions.text: The phenomenon known as "Washerwoman's hand," characterized by wrinkled and pale appearance of the skin on the hands and feet, is most indicative of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Submersion in water

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Washerwoman's hand is a key indicator of submersion in water and is seen as early wrinkling and pale changes to the skin, especially on the hands and feet, after prolonged immersion.
  • ➤ Washerwoman's hand
  • ➤ submersion in water

questions.text: As per Hasse’s rule, During the first 5 months of pregnancy, Age (months) is: ​​​​​​​

options.label: A
options.text: Square root of crown-rump length in cms

options.label: B
options.text: Square root of crown-heel length in cms

options.label: C
options.text: Crown-rump length in cms divided by 5

options.label: D
options.text: Crown-heel length in cms divided by 5

questions.correct_answer: B. Square root of crown-heel length in cms
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Square root of crown-heel length in cms

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During the first five months of pregnancy, fetal age (in months) can be estimated by taking the square root of the crown-heel length in centimeters , according to Hasse’s rule .
  • ➤ first five months
  • ➤ square root of the crown-heel length in centimeters
  • ➤ Hasse’s rule

questions.text: The test in which weight of lungs is compared with body weight is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ploucquet's Test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ploucquet's Test compares the weight of the lungs to the body weight to determine if a newborn was born alive, based on the expansion and weight increase of the lungs.
  • ➤ Ploucquet's Test

questions.text: Police officers found a completely burnt dead body of a person in a forest. They suspect that someone might have killed him and later burnt the dead body to avoid identification. Doctor while conducting the postmortem, found a significant finding in the larynx as shown below. This is suggestive of.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Antemortem Burns

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Soot deposition in the larynx is a strong indicator of antemortem burns , as it signifies that the individual was breathing during the fire, inhaling soot into the respiratory tract before death.
  • ➤ Soot deposition in the larynx
  • ➤ antemortem burns

questions.text: A 40-year-old cyclist who had been riding outdoors for hours collapses and loses consciousness. Bystanders mention that the cyclist was not adequately hydrating during the ride. Upon assessment, the individual's body temperature is 106°F (41°C). What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Heat Stroke

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Heat stroke is diagnosed when body temperature exceeds 104°F (40°C) and is accompanied by central nervous system dysfunction such as confusion or unconsciousness. Immediate medical intervention is critical to prevent organ damage or death.
  • ➤ Heat stroke
  • ➤ 104°F (40°C)

questions.text: Police officer brings a 15-year-old male child to doctor for medical examination. Mother of the child gives the history that his uncle has been threatening and sexual assualting him for past 2 years, which she came to know now and complained the police. After doing the complete examination, doctor examines the anus, which shows features as in the picture below. This is suggestive of?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Normal Anus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A normal anal examination does not rule out a history of sexual abuse. The anal tissue is highly elastic and capable of healing quickly without leaving visible signs of trauma.
  • ➤ Absence of physical signs such as tears, bruising, or fissures is common, especially if significant time has passed since the last incident of alleged abuse.
  • ➤ Forensic evaluations should rely not only on physical examination findings but also on detailed history, psychosocial context, and other corroborative evidence to arrive at a comprehensive assessment.

questions.text: A woman gives birth to two children at same time. One foetus is 32 weeks old on delivery and the second one is 36 weeks old. How is this Possible?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Superfetation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Superfetation is the occurrence of a second pregnancy during an existing one, leading to the development of two fetuses of different gestational ages.
  • ➤ Superfetation

questions.text: A rape victim is examined in a hospital and a specimen from her vagina is subjected to staining by 10% HCl, potassium iodide, iodine and water. Dark brown rhombic shaped crystals appear immediately. Which test was done?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Florence test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Florence test is used to detect semen by identifying dark brown rhombic-shaped crystals of choline iodide, making it a crucial forensic tool in cases of sexual assault.
  • ➤ Florence test
  • ➤ dark brown rhombic-shaped crystals

questions.text: A factory worker was brought to the emergency room after consuming wood spirt with complaints of headache, vomiting and blurred vision. What treatment will you give the patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Fomepizole

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fomepizole is the preferred antidote for methanol poisoning , as it inhibits the enzyme alcohol dehydrogenase, preventing the conversion of methanol into its toxic metabolites.
  • ➤ Fomepizole
  • ➤ methanol poisoning

questions.text: In OPC poisoning, treatment was done with atropine and pralidoxime. Hyperthermia occurs. What could be the cause?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Atropine Toxicity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Atropine toxicity can lead to hyperthermia in the treatment of organophosphate poisoning due to its anticholinergic effects, which inhibit sweating and impair the body's ability to regulate temperature.
  • ➤ Atropine toxicity
  • ➤ hyperthermia
  • ➤ organophosphate poisoning

questions.text: A child before playing consumed fruit from the garden. After some time, he developed a high fever, confusion, photophobia, and unable to urinate. What are the likely causative agent and the appropriate antidote used in this case?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Datura, Physostigmine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Datura poisoning presents with anticholinergic symptoms such as high fever, confusion, photophobia, and urinary retention, and the antidote is physostigmine , a cholinesterase inhibitor.
  • ➤ Datura poisoning
  • ➤ anticholinergic symptoms
  • ➤ physostigmine

questions.text: A 7-year-old child from an environment presents with pallor, fatigue, and abdominal discomfort. Laboratory investigations reveal a hemoglobin level of 9.5 g/dL and a peripheral blood smear demonstrates a peculiar finding shown below. Which of the following differential diagnoses is most likely responsible for this finding in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Viral infection affecting erythropoiesis, causing aberrant RNA synthesis.

options.label: B
options.text: Lead poisoning leads to abnormal iron metabolism, leading to intracellular iron accumulation within red blood cells.

options.label: C
options.text: Autoimmune hemolytic anemia, caused by the production of autoantibodies against red blood cell antigens.

options.label: D
options.text: Lead poisoning affects heme synthesis and resulting in aggregates of ribosomal material within red blood cells.

questions.correct_answer: D. Lead poisoning affects heme synthesis and resulting in aggregates of ribosomal material within red blood cells.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Lead poisoning affecting heme synthesis and resulting in aggregates of ribosomal material within red blood cells.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lead poisoning disrupts heme synthesis , resulting in basophilic stippling in red blood cells, a key diagnostic feature.
  • ➤ Lead poisoning
  • ➤ heme synthesis
  • ➤ basophilic stippling

questions.text: What is the active principle of the poison shown in the image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Bhilawanol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The marking nut contains the active principles bhilawanol and semecarpol , which cause severe skin irritation and can be toxic when ingested.
  • ➤ marking nut
  • ➤ bhilawanol
  • ➤ semecarpol

questions.text: Which of the following chelating agents is recommended for acute Lead poisoning with signs of encephalopathy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Dimercaprol + Calcium EDTA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For acute lead poisoning with encephalopathy , the combination of Dimercaprol (BAL) and Calcium EDTA is recommended to safely chelate lead and prevent worsening of the condition.
  • ➤ acute lead poisoning with encephalopathy
  • ➤ Dimercaprol (BAL) and Calcium EDTA

questions.text: A patient was brought to casualty with seizures. He had multiple episodes and was taking herbal medicines for the same. He was conscious in between the episodes. During the episodes, he had arching of his back. What is the likely cause?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Strychnine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Strychnine poisoning is characterized by recurrent seizures with arching of the back (opisthotonos) and consciousness between episodes , making it the most likely cause in this scenario.
  • ➤ Strychnine poisoning
  • ➤ recurrent seizures
  • ➤ arching of the back (opisthotonos)
  • ➤ consciousness between episodes

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presents to ED in a coma with CPR in progress. A friend found him in the schoolyard. His friend confesses that the patient has been depressed over the past several days. His initial labs reveal hypocalcemia and a severe metabolic acidosis. The urine shows calcium oxalate crystals. What was the toxic ingestion?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ethylene Glycol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ethylene glycol poisoning is characterized by severe metabolic acidosis , hypocalcemia , and calcium oxalate crystals in the urine due to the toxic metabolites of ethylene glycol.
  • ➤ Ethylene glycol poisoning
  • ➤ severe metabolic acidosis
  • ➤ hypocalcemia
  • ➤ calcium oxalate crystals

questions.text: An approximately twenty-something year old female presents to the emergency department after she collapsed outside a bar. Physical Examination: T: 97.5°F HR: 60 bpm RR: 5 breaths per minute BP: 75/57 mm Hg Pupils are miotic but equal. Pulmonary: Clear to auscultation. CV: Regular rate and rhythm. Abdomen: Normal Neurologic: GCS = 6 (E1V1M4). Best treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Naloxone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of opioid overdose , characterized by severe respiratory depression and miosis , Naloxone is the antidote of choice for rapid reversal of the opioid effects.
  • ➤ opioid overdose
  • ➤ severe respiratory depression
  • ➤ miosis
  • ➤ Naloxone

questions.text: A patient came with complaints of hair loss. His wife mentions that she has noticed some behavioral changes. The doctor notices that there is a loss of eyebrows on the lateral side. He then concludes by examining the nails. What is the type of poisoning in this case?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Thallium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thallium poisoning is associated with hair loss , including the loss of lateral eyebrows, behavioral changes , and nail findings such as Mees' lines .
  • ➤ Thallium poisoning
  • ➤ hair loss
  • ➤ behavioral changes
  • ➤ Mees' lines

questions.text: Which of these is not a symptom of cocaine poisoning?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Bradycardia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bradycardia is not a symptom of cocaine poisoning . Cocaine causes sympathomimetic effects like tachycardia , myocardial ischemia , hyperthermia , and agitation .
  • ➤ Bradycardia
  • ➤ cocaine poisoning
  • ➤ sympathomimetic effects
  • ➤ tachycardia
  • ➤ myocardial ischemia
  • ➤ hyperthermia
  • ➤ agitation

questions.text: A 28-year-old male is brought to the emergency department with agitation, dilated pupils, and tachycardia. He appears restless and paranoid, and he is sweating profusely. His blood pressure is elevated. What is the likely cause of these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Acute Cocaine poisoning

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute cocaine poisoning presents with sympathomimetic symptoms such as agitation, dilated pupils, tachycardia, elevated blood pressure , and sweating , making it the most likely cause in this scenario.
  • ➤ Acute cocaine poisoning
  • ➤ sympathomimetic symptoms
  • ➤ agitation, dilated pupils, tachycardia, elevated blood pressure
  • ➤ sweating

questions.text: Knock out drop is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Chloral hydrate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chloral hydrate is known as the "knockout drop" due to its historical use in incapacitating individuals by inducing unconsciousness.
  • ➤ Chloral hydrate
  • ➤ "knockout drop"

questions.text: A farmer was sleeping in the field, and he felt a sting on his leg. He saw something moving away quickly. He then got drowsy and was taken to the hospital. He developed pain around the site and continued to bleed profusely from the wound site. The wound became red with blisters. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Viper

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A viper bite causes hemotoxic effects , leading to local bleeding, severe pain, redness, and blistering , along with potential systemic effects like drowsiness.
  • ➤ viper bite
  • ➤ hemotoxic effects
  • ➤ local bleeding, severe pain, redness, and blistering

questions.text: A 30-year-old individual presents to the emergency department with severe pain, restlessness, hypertension, tachycardia, and sweating after being stung by a scorpion. The sting site is red and swollen, with no signs of necrosis. What is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient's condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Apply a tourniquet proximal to the sting site.

options.label: D
options.text: Cleanse the wound and apply ice packs.

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Administer Prazosin.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of scorpion stings causing adrenergic symptoms such as hypertension and tachycardia, the administration of Prazosin is the most appropriate treatment to block the excessive catecholamine effects.
  • ➤ scorpion stings
  • ➤ adrenergic symptoms
  • ➤ Prazosin

questions.text: Activated charcoal is ineffective in poisoning of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Ethyl alcohol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Activated charcoal is ineffective in cases of ethyl alcohol poisoning because alcohols are rapidly absorbed and not well adsorbed by charcoal.
  • ➤ Activated charcoal
  • ➤ ineffective
  • ➤ ethyl alcohol poisoning

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient arrives at the hospital emergency department presenting with gastrointestinal distress. The patient complains of severe abdominal pain, frequent vomiting, and watery diarrhea. During the physical examination, the medical team observes that the patient's stools emit an unusual faint glow. The patient appears disoriented and fatigued. Medical history reveals that the patient attended a local festival the previous day and consumed various food items there. The following exposures might be contributing to which substance toxication?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Phosphorus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Phosphorus poisoning is characterized by gastrointestinal distress and glowing stools. It can occur due to ingestion of substances containing phosphorus, such as rodent poison. Recognizing glowing stools is crucial in diagnosing phosphorus toxicity.

questions.text: A hiker in a forested area is bitten by a snake while exploring. The snake's identification is uncertain, and the hiker begins to experience symptoms such as swelling, pain, and bruising at the bite site. The hiker remains conscious but is anxious. What is the most appropriate initial first aid response for this snake bite?

options.label: A
options.text: Applying a tourniquet above the bite site to restrict blood flow and prevent venom spread.

options.label: B
options.text: Cutting open the wound and attempting to suck out the venom.

options.label: C
options.text: Immobilizing the affected limb at or slightly below heart level and transporting the person to a medical facility.

options.label: D
options.text: Applying ice packs directly to the bite area to reduce swelling and pain.

questions.correct_answer: C. Immobilizing the affected limb at or slightly below heart level and transporting the person to a medical facility.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Immobilizing the affected limb at or slightly below heart level and transporting the person to a medical facility.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the event of a snake bite, the correct first aid involves immobilizing the affected limb at or slightly below heart level and seeking immediate medical attention. Tourniquets, cutting the wound, and applying ice are ineffective and potentially harmful.

questions.text: A 30-year-old individual diagnosed with schizophrenia commits an act that would otherwise be considered a criminal offense. The act was committed during a period of acute psychotic episode. The individual's medical history indicates sporadic adherence to prescribed antipsychotic medication. The prosecution has charged the individual with the offense. Based on the provided information, which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the applicability of Section 84 of IPC in this case?

options.label: A
options.text: The accused cannot invoke Section 84 since the act was committed while not adhering to prescribed medication.

options.label: B
options.text: Section 84 applies as the offence was committed during psychotic episode, regardless of medication adherence.

options.label: C
options.text: Section 84 is inapplicable due to the sporadic nature of the individual's symptoms.

options.label: D
options.text: The accused can only invoke Section 84 if the act was committed during a state of complete unconsciousness.

questions.correct_answer: B. Section 84 applies as the offence was committed during psychotic episode, regardless of medication adherence.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Section 84 applies if the accused's schizophrenia diagnosis is confirmed, regardless of medication adherence.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Section 84 of the IPC provides protection from criminal liability if an individual commits an offense while suffering from a mental illness that prevents them from understanding the nature of their actions. In cases of schizophrenia or psychosis, the focus is on the individual's mental state during the act, not medication adherence or the regularity of symptoms.
